page.title: 01BANGOR AND LLANDEGAI
page.content: The southern half of the small cathedral city of Bangor dominates the northwest of this area. Part of Bangor's central district is included, compressed into a narrow valley between steeply rising but low ridges. This part is mainly 19th - early 20th century houses and shops, with some science and other buildings of the University College of North Wales, and the railway station. Bangor has expanded by infill and extension southwestwards along the valley followed by the Caemarvon road, and along the northwestern ridge. Housing dominates, but schools, a technical college, commercial and public service buildings are also present. Across the southwestern ridge with its golf course is a large housing estate and a new industrial estate. Beyond this, on the eastern edge of the block,
